repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - Banking Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Banking Sector Adjustment Loan
            (BSAL) was rated as highly satisfactory. The key lessons
            learned are: 1) BSAL provides strong evidence to prove the
            principle that program ownership must underpin reform
            implementation for it to be successful. 2) The economic
            crisis or near crisis situation in Pakistan provided the
            opportunity for taking strong reform measures. However,
            gains from reforms taken in response to a crisis have to be
            consolidated quickly because, as the crisis eases, vested
            interests quickly return to slow reforms, if not reverse
            them altogether. 3) BSAL is among the first projects in the
            Bank that deal directly with the issue of governance and
            corruption. Key reform measures correctly revolved around
            insulating the banking system from vested interests. 4)
            BSAL's preparation was a case of very close
            collaborative process with International Monetary Fund and
            the productive partnership that such a collaboration
            engenders to the benefit of the client. 5) BSAL correctly
            tackled the flow problem first. 6) In view of the banking
            problems in Pakistan, the primordial objective is to achieve
            improved corporate governance by selling the nationalized
            commercial banks and development finance institutions to the
            most reputable and qualified private investors. To help
            achieve this objective, participation by reputable
            international banks is encouraged.

5085871.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - Banking Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Banking Sector Adjustment Loan
            (BSAL) Project provides balance of payments assistance to
            Pakistan in implementing a stabilization program and
            structural reforms in a distressed banking sector. This
            operation supports implementation of major short-term reform
            measures in the banking sector that have arrested the flow
            of bad loans, curtailed loss-making, and conserved the
            assets of nationalized commercial banks and development
            finance institutions while they were being prepared for
            privatization. reforms measures include bringing prudential
            regulations and financial disclosure standards to
            international levels to increase transparency; reducing
            market distortions to increase the efficiency of financial
            intermediation; and strengthening legal and judicial
            processes to enable a more effective enforcement of
            financial contracts. The BSAL supports fiscal stabilization,
            improves the private sector s access to banking services,
            and helps protect those directly affected by the reform
            process. Moreover, the BSAL centers around the core issue of
            governance in banking.
